facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 402 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 402 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 15, 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 236 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 15, 1956 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 236 of 1949.

facts.text: 259 bales of cloth delivered on May 10, 1946, at Wadi Bunder station on G.I. Railway to Giellekhola on D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR., J.-This appeal arises out of a suit for recovery of damages in respect of 90 bales out of 259 bales of cloth delivered on May 10, 1946, at Wadi Bunder station on the Great Indian Peninsula Railway, hereafter called the G. I. Railway, to be carried from there to Giellekhola a station on the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway, hereafter called the D. H. Railway.

facts.text: Goods carried over G.I.P. Railway, East Indian Railway (I. Railway), Bengal Assam Railway (A. Railway), and D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: In order to reach Giellekhola the goods had to be carried over four railways, namely, the G. P. Railway, East Indian Railway, hereafter Called the I. Railway, the Bengal Assam Railway, hereafter called the A. Railway and the D. H. Railway.

facts.text: Railways other than D.H. Railway owned by Government of India; D.H. Railway owned by private company.

anchor.surface_text: The goods had been booked through to be carried over all these railways. At all material times the railways other than the D. H. Railway, were owned by the Government of India, the D. H. Railway being owned by a private companypany.

facts.text: D.H. Railway Company went into liquidation; liquidators brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: At some stage of the litigation the D. H. Railway Company went into liquidation and the liquidators were brought on the record.

facts.text: 169 bales delivered to appellant on June 7, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: On June, 7, 1946, 169 bales were delivered to the appellant to whom the Railway Receipt had been endorsed.

facts.text: 90 bales traced at Gadkhali on A. Railway about September 1946.

anchor.surface_text: About September 1946, the wagon companytaining the 90 bales Was traced at a station called Gadkhali on the A. Railway.

facts.text: 90 bales arrived at Giellekhola shortly prior to December 21, 1946, in damaged condition.

anchor.surface_text: Further companyrespondence ensued and the 90 bales actually arrived at Giellekhola shortly prior to December 21, 1946, on which date, having found the companysignment in a very damaged companydition,

facts.text: Open delivery of 90 bales given on February 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant requested the D. H. Railway to give open delivery. Thereafter on February 12, 1947 , open delivery of the companytents of the 90 bales was given to the appellant.

facts.text: Damage assessed at Rs. 27,920-13-6 by agreement between appellant, B.A. Railway, and D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the damage done to the goods was assessed by agreement between the appellant, the B. A. Railway and the H. Railway at Rs. 27,920-13-6.

facts.text: Notice under s.80 CPC sent on January 29, 1948, demanding Rs. 34,192.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter on January 29, 1948, sent a numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure to the Secretary of the Railway Department, Government of India, making a demand of Rs. 34,192 for damage suffered by it as a result of the negligence of the railways in carrying the goods.

facts.text: Suit filed on April 9, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore., on April 9, 1948, filed the suit for damages.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed suit against D.H. Railway for Rs. 27,920-13-6.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed against the D.H. Railway way only by the trial Court for Rs. 27,920-13-6.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court allowed D.H. Railway appeal and dismissed cross-objection.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the appeal and dismissed the cross-objection. Hence the present appeal.

facts.text: Appellant sent telegram on July 1, 1946, to General Manager D.H. Railway for early delivery.

anchor.surface_text: The admitted fact are briefly these. The appellant had companysigned 259 bales of cloth from Wadi-Bunder., a station on the Great Indian Peninsular Railway  number the Central Railway  to Giellekhola, a station on the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway  number in liquidation  on May 10, 1946. Out of these bales 169 reached the destination on or about June 7, 1946. As the remaining bales had number reached the destination the appellant sent a telegram on July 1,1946,

facts.text: Letter dated July 9, 1946, confirming telegram to D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: to the General Manager of the D. H. Railway requesting him to give early delivery of those bales. By a letter dated July 9, 1946, the appellant companyfirmed the telegram and requested the General Manager to see that the remaining bales reached the destination immediately.

facts.text: Letter dated December 21, 1946, to D.H. Railway stating consignment arrived in damaged condition, requesting open delivery.

anchor.surface_text: to the letter dated December 21, 1946, addressed by the appellant to the D. H. Railway stating that they have companye to know that the companysignment had arrived at Giellekhola in a very damaged companydition and requesting that open delivery of the companysignment be given immediately.

facts.text: Open delivery given to appellant's assistant manager Tulsi Ram on February 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Open delivery was given to the appellants assistant manager, Tulsi Ram, P.W. 1, on February 12, 1947, by the Commercial inspector, D.H. Railway.

facts.text: Damage jointly assessed at Rs. 27,920-13-6 by Commercial Inspector D.H. Railway, Claims Inspector B.A. Railway, and Tulsi Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The damage was jointly assessed by the Commercial Inspector, D. H. Railway, and the Claims Inspector, Bengal Assam Railway, at Rs. 27,920-13-6 and the assessment list was signed by them as well as by Tulsi Ram.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal in part, restored trial court decree against D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: By COURT In view of the majority opinion the Court allowed the appeal in part, set aside the decree of the High Court in so far as the D. H. Railway is companycerned and restored that of the trial companyrt.

facts.text: No notice under s.77 Railways Act given to G.I.P., E.I., or B.A. Railways within 6 months.

anchor.surface_text: No such numberice was given by the appellant to the G. I. P. Railway administration or the E. I. Railway administration or the B. Railway administration within six months of booking the companysignment

facts.text: Telegram and letter of July 1 and 9, 1946 constituted notice u/s 77 for D.H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: Bearing in mind these companysideration we think that the letter of July 9, 1946  Ex. I  y    which was sent,within six months of booking the companysignment amounts to a sufficient numberice for the purposes of s. 77.

holdings.text: The letter of July 9, 1946 which was sent within six months of booking the consignment amounts to a sufficient notice for the purposes of s. 77 of the Railways Act for the D. H. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: Bearing in mind these considerations we think that the letter of July 9, 1946  Ex. I  y    which was sent,within six months of booking the consignment amounts to a sufficient notice for the purposes of s. 77.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal construction of notice required; object to enable railway enquiry satisfied; non-delivery implies claim for compensation as breach of contract entails damages.

holdings.text: No notice under s. 77 given to G.I.P., E.I. or B.A. Railways within six months, so suit rightly dismissed against them.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the language of s.77 it would appear that a notice thereunder must be given to every railway administration against whom a suit is eventually filed. No such notice was given by the appellant to the G. I. P. Railway administration or the E. I. Railway administration or the B. A. Railway administration within six months of booking the consignment and, therefore, in so far as they are concerned the suit must be held to have been rightly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.77 requires notice to each railway sued; literal reading; no notice provided within time.

holdings.text: Article 30 of the Limitation Act applies, not Article 31, as suit is for compensation for injury to goods that were delivered.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the appropriate article would be Art. 30 and not Art. 31 because what the appellant is claiming is compensation for the damage to the goods which were eventually delivered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between non-delivery/delay (Art.31) and injury to delivered goods (Art.30).

holdings.text: Suit not barred by limitation under Art. 30 as D. H. Railway failed to discharge burden of proving damage occurred more than one year before institution.

anchor.surface_text: No attempt has been made on behalf of the D. H. Railway to show that the damage in fact occurred more than one year before the suit was instituted. ... Upon the material before us it is not possible to say that the suit was instituted beyond one year of the accrual of the cause of action. It is, therefore, not barred by time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on railway per precedent to prove date of injury; external appearance knowledge insufficient for contents damage; no evidence led.

holdings.text: Under s. 80 Railways Act, when consignment received damaged from delivering railway, burden shifts to it to prove damage not on its system; presumption not rebutted here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial burden on consignor shifts upon proof of damage at delivery; delivering railway must show prior damage; no evidence provided.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed in part; High Court decree set aside as to D. H. Railway; trial court decree restored holding it liable for Rs. 27,920-13-6.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this view we must allow the appeal against the D. H. Railway. ... We, therefore, allow the appeal in part, set aside the decree of the High Court in so far as the D. H. Railway is concerned and restore that of the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on notice, limitation, and liability; majority opinion.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the language of s.77 it would appear that a notice thereunder must be given to every railway administration against whom a suit is eventually filed. No such notice was given by the appellant to the G. I. P. Railway administration or the E. I. Railway administration or the B. A. Railway administration within six months of booking the consignment and, therefore, in so far as they are concerned the suit must be held to have been rightly dismissed.
By COURT In view of the majority opinion the Court allowed the appeal in part, set aside the decree of the High Court in so far as the D. H. Railway is concerned and restored that of the trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: No attempt has been made on behalf of the D. H. Railway to show that the damage in fact occurred more than one year before the suit was instituted. ...
